results.title: The Colorado River Is Shrinking. See What’s Using All the Water.
results.abstract: Hint: It’s less about long showers and more about what’s for dinner.

results.adx_keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Salads;Summer (Season);Salad Dressings;Tomatoes;Corn
results.title: Kick Off Summer With These 5 Breezy Make-Ahead Salads
results.abstract: The best-kept secret about the season’s produce? It’s amazing in quick-to-make sides that only get better with time.

media.caption: Clockwise from top left, a verdant potato salad, a savory fruit salad, a corn salad with a buttermilk dressing, a zucchini pasta salad and a sesame-tinged tomato salad are easy-to-transport sides that are ready for your next party.
media.copyright: Armando Rafael for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Cyd Raftus McDowell.

results.title: My A.I. Lover
results.abstract: Three women reflect on the complexities of their relationships with their A.I. companions.

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Bicycles and Bicycling;Book Trade and Publishing;LeMond, Greg;Strava Inc;Rizzoli International Publications;Europe
results.title: To Find Europe’s Best Bike Routes, a Cycling Writer Asked the Crowd
results.abstract: The longtime sports journalist Claude Droussent discusses his new guidebook to cycling in Europe, which uses data from the fitness app Strava, and the growing role bicycles play in worldwide travel.

media.caption: Claude Droussent riding his bike in the Alpilles mountains, between Avignon and Marseille in France.

results.adx_keywords: Television;internal-sub-only;Comedy and Humor;Seinfeld, Jerry;David, Larry;Alexander, Jason;Richards, Michael;Louis-Dreyfus, Julia;National Broadcasting Co
results.title: What’s the Deal With Adulthood? 25 Years Later, ‘Seinfeld’ Feels Revelatory.
results.abstract: The show about nothing ended in May 1998. But in an era when priorities are being re-evaluated, the sitcom has taken on new relevance.

media.caption: The polarizing “Seinfeld” finale, which aired on May 14, 1998, put Jerry and friends on trial for the attitudes and behavior they displayed over nine seasons.
media.copyright: Joseph Del Valle/NBCU Photo Bank/NBCUniversal, via Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Musk, Elon;DeSantis, Ron;Trump, Donald J;Twitter
results.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman, Ryan Mac and Nicholas Nehamas
results.title: DeSantis Set to Announce 2024 Run on Twitter With Elon Musk
results.abstract: Adding a twist to the beginning of his presidential campaign, the Florida governor is expected to appear on a live audio conversation with Mr. Musk, the social platform’s owner, on Wednesday evening.

media.caption: Elon Musk has previously expressed his support for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
media.copyright: Pool photo by Ludovic Marin; Sophie Park for The New York Times

results.title: How Parents Can Actually Help Teens Navigate Social Media
results.abstract: The U.S. surgeon general and the American Psychological Association have urged parents to monitor adolescents for “problematic” social media use. We asked experts for some realistic and effective ways to do this.

results.byline: By Sharon Otterman and Yana Paskova
results.title: A Movement to Make Workplaces ‘Menopause Friendly’
results.abstract: What is a menopause-friendly workplace? Women in cities like New York may soon find out, as U.S. companies adopt practices that were already spreading in Britain.

media.caption: Author Jennifer Weiss-Wolf, left, speaks with Davina Pardo, right, a filmmaker, at an event in which women discussed menopause at Luminary, a networking and education company, in Manhattan.

results.title: Moving Is a Monumental Task for Many Older Americans. These Organizers Can Help.
results.abstract: Senior move managers may spend weeks or months helping seniors and their families sort through belongings, pack and move into a new home.

media.caption: Ray and Beth Nygren in their new two-bedroom independent living apartment in Auburn, Wash., where they moved with the help of a senior move manager.

results.title: What Christian Nationalism Has Done to My State and My Faith Is a Sin
results.abstract: Wyoming’s new crop of lawmakers seems intent on stripping us of our autonomy and our ability to make decisions for ourselves.

results.title: How the Arts Can Benefit Your Mental Health (No Talent Required)
results.abstract: Drawing, music and writing can elevate your mood. Here are some easy ways to welcome them into your life.

results.adx_keywords: Heat and Heat Waves;Global Warming;Environmental Science & Technology (Journal);Phoenix (Ariz)
results.title: Heat Wave and Blackout Would Send Half of Phoenix to E.R., Study Says
results.abstract: New research warns that nearly 800,000 residents would need emergency medical care for heat stroke and other illnesses in an extended power failure. Other cities are also at risk.

media.caption: A view of the Phoenix from South Mountain last summer. An industry analysis released this month warns of the threat of citywide blackouts during heatwaves.
media.copyright: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Huntington's Disease;Research;Genetics and Heredity;DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid);your-feed-health;your-feed-science;CHDI Foundation;Universidad Simon Bolivar;Colombia
results.byline: By Jennie Erin Smith and Charlie Cordero
results.title: Sought Out by Science, and Then Forgotten
results.abstract: Four decades ago, medical researchers reached out to ailing families in Colombia for insights into Huntington’s disease. Scientists are just now following up, hoping it’s not too late.

media.caption: José Echevarría was helped to bed by his mother, Nohora Vásquez, at home in Piojó, Colombia. Mr. Echeverría has Huntington’s disease, a hereditary, progressive neurodegenerative disease caused by a genetic mutation.
media.copyright: Charlie Cordero for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Dictionaries;Black People;English Language;Research;Language and Languages;Gates, Henry Louis Jr;Harvard University;Oxford University Press
results.title: The First 10 Words of the African American English Dictionary Are In
results.abstract: An exclusive look at a dictionary consisting entirely of words created or reinvented by Black people. (Don’t worry: All three variants of “bussin” are included.)

media.caption: Prof. Henry Louis Gates Jr., a decorated scholar of Black history and culture, is the editor in chief of the Oxford Dictionary of African American English. One of his proudest possessions is a first edition of the Samuel Johnson dictionary.
media.copyright: Cole Barash for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Priests;Sex Crimes;Clergy;Child Abuse and Neglect;Raoul, Kwame;Madigan, Lisa;Bernardin, Joseph L;Roman Catholic Church;Chicago (Ill);Illinois
results.title: Sex Abuse in Catholic Church: Over 1,900 Minors Abused in Illinois, State Says
results.abstract: A new report by the attorney general of Illinois covering decades names more than 450 credibly accused sexual abusers, including priests and lay religious brothers.

media.caption: More than 450 credibly accused child sex abusers ministered in the Catholic Church in Illinois in the decades since 1950, the state attorney general said Tuesday.

results.adx_keywords: Restaurants;Luxury Goods and Services;Carbone (Manhattan, NY, Restaurant);Major Food Group;Dallas (Tex)
results.title: For Diners With Deep Pockets, Dallas Is the New Dubai
results.abstract: The city’s booming economy is attracting a flock of luxury restaurants from other cities. Is that a good thing for local cuisine?

media.caption: Several national restaurant groups catering to big spenders have opened outposts in Dallas. La Neta Cocina y Lounge offers a $95 lobster taco served in a cheese-stuffed tortilla.
media.copyright: JerSean Golatt for The New York Times
